contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox person |name = Christopher Anstey |image = Christopher Anstey with his daughter by William Hoare.jpg |caption = Christopher Anstey with his daughter, by [[William Hoare]], circa 1777 |birth_date = 31 October, 1724 |birth_place = [[Brinkley, Cambridgeshire]] |death_date = 3 August, 1805 (aged 80) |death_place = [[Bath, Somerset]] |nationality = [[England|English]] |occupation= writer, poet |notable_works = ''The New Bath Guide'' (1766)}} '''Christopher Anstey''' (31 October, 1724 – 3 August, 1805) was an English writer and poet. Anstey was the son of Dr. Anstey, a wealthy clergyman, the rector of [[Brinkley, Cambridgeshire|Brinkley (Cambridgeshire)]] where he was born. He was educated at [[Eton College]] and [[King's College, Cambridge]],<ref>{{Venn|ANSY742C}}</ref> where he distinguished himself for his Latin verses. He became a fellow of his college (1745); but the degree of M.A. was withheld from him, owing to the offence caused by a speech made by him beginning: "''{{lang|la|Doctores sine doctrina, magistri artium sine artibus, et baccalaurei baculo potius quam lauro digni}}''" (Doctors without doctrine, artless Masters of Arts, and Bachelors more worthy of the rod than the laurel). In 1754 he succeeded to the family estates, including [[Trumpington, Cambridgeshire|Anstey Hall, Trumpington]] and left Cambridge; and two years later he married Ann, the daughter of Felix Calvert of Albury Hall, Herts. For some time Anstey lived the life of a country squire, bringing up thirteen children, and published nothing of any note, though he cultivated letters as well as his estates. He served as [[High Sheriff of Cambridgeshire and Huntingdonshire]] for 1770-71. <ref> {{cite web| url = http://www.brlsi.org/events-proceedings/proceedings/25151| title= Christopher Anstey:A life in 18th Century Bath|publisher = Bath Royal Literary and Scientific Institution|accessdate = 26 June 2013}} </ref> Some visits were made to Bath, however, where from 1770 until his death in 1805, he made No. 4 [[Royal Crescent]] his permanent home, (albeit the plaque recording this is actually displayed outside No. 5) <ref name="lowndes">{{cite book|last=Lowndes|first=William|title=The Royal Crescent in Bath|publisher=Redcliffe Press|year=1981|isbn=978-0-905459-34-9}}</ref> where in 1766 he penned his famous rhymed letters, ''The New Bath Guide'' or ''Memoirs of the Blunderhead Family...'', a satirical poem of considerable sparkle, about the adventures of the "Blunderhead" family in [[Bath, England|Bath]], from which [[Tobias Smollett]] is said to have drawn largely in his ''[[The Expedition of Humphry Clinker]]''. The work had immediate success, and was enthusiastically praised for its original kind of humour by Walpole and Gray. The ''Election Ball, in Poetical Letters from Mr Inkle at Bath to his Wife at Gloucester'' (1776) sustained the reputation won by the Guide. He made many other excursions into literature which are hardly remembered, and ended his days as a country squire at the age of eighty. His ''Poetical Works'' were collected in 1808 (2 vols.) by the author's son [[John Anstey (poet)|John Anstey]] (d. 1819), himself author of ''The Pleader's Guide'' (1796), in the same vein with the ''New Bath Guide''. Anstey was buried at St. Swithin's Church in [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]] but has a white marble memorial tablet in Poets' Corner (the South Transept) of [[Westminster Abbey]]. == References == {{Reflist}} * {{A Short Biographical Dictionary of English Literature}} * {{1911}} ==External links== {{wikisource-author}} *{{worldcat id|lccn-n85-17759}} {{Authority control|VIAF=39731521}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Anstey, Christopher | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = October 31, 1724 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Brinkley, Cambridgeshire]] | DATE OF DEATH = August 3, 1805 | PLACE OF DEATH = [[Bath, Somerset]] }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Anstey, Christopher}} [[Category:1724 births]] [[Category:1805 deaths]] [[Category:People from East Cambridgeshire (district)]] [[Category:English poets]] [[Category:People educated at Eton College]] [[Category:Alumni of King's College, Cambridge]] [[Category:Fellows of King's College, Cambridge]] [[Category:High Sheriffs of Cambridgeshire and Huntingdonshire]]
